SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, experiencing fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. He attributes the symptoms to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. The patient has been adhering to his medications but has struggled with his diet due to kitchen renovations, leading to eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever, chills. Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses bloating. No chest pain.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath during exertion. Slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was attempting to change a light bulb while on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, specifically over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid, but overall alignment is proper.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat, but they did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes, which resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening and pain management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He is managing his depression well with medication.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. His blood pressure in the office today is 120/80 mmHg.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He reports occasional shortness of breath during humid weather and when running 4-5 miles daily. He also experiences some chest pounding during exertion, which resolves.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Occasional chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Occasional shortness of breath during humid weather and exertion.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: He is doing well with medication management.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to continue current management strategies.

Prior Lobectomy.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
• Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is controlled and improved compared to previous years.
• Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return if the pain does not improve after one week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also mentions increased anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy in 1996.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: Occasional, once or twice a year.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs or gallops.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezing or crackles.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
2. Hematologist referral: Sent to Dr. Flores for further evaluation and management.
3. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily, with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.
4. Monitor for any worsening symptoms and contact the clinic with any concerns.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy appointments. Follow bowel prep instructions provided. Schedule an appointment with the hematologist, Dr. Flores. Call the clinic with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward, a 52-year-old male, presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile demonstrating a low TSH, and an MRI revealing a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

During the consultation, Mr. Ward described his headaches as a dull nagging ache located behind his eyes, with a gradual onset and increasing severity over the past three months. He also mentioned recently bumping into door frames. No other significant symptoms were reported.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Alcohol, smoking, and recreational drug use: None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision before surgery.
3. Schedule surgery using a transsphenoidal approach, discussing the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery.
4. Monitor the patient's vision after surgery to assess improvement.

End of note.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. The patient reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and felt worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient visited the ER, where she had a normal cardiac workup, including EKG and blood tests. The ER suspected a GI-related issue and referred her to our clinic. Since the initial episode, the patient has not experienced any recurrence of chest pain or difficulty swallowing.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Gallbladder removal.

Surgical
Cholecystectomy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

No significant social history reported.

FAMILY HISTORY

No significant family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None reported.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for weight loss, weight gain, abdominal pain, and abnormal bowel movements.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which have since resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020 with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient reported a stressful job transition during the time of her symptoms, which may have contributed to her condition.

PLAN

1. Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney evaluation for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for kidney evaluation. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. The patient has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned potential kidney anomalies associated with her syndrome.

The patient has normal wet diaper frequency (8-10 per day) and is well-hydrated. She is currently on a dairy-free diet, consuming pea protein milk, water, and occasionally water with a small amount of juice.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Prematurity.
Gastroesophageal reflux.

Family History
No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
2. If the ultrasound shows abnormalities, determine next steps and future follow-up at the town center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.
3. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow-up as needed based on the findings. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her outstretched arms. The patient reports severe pain, rated 9 out of 10, and swelling in her right wrist. She has been icing, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation, bony crepitus, pain on flexion, extension, radial and ulnar deviation, and difficulty making a tight fist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient her current symptoms and diagnosis. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. We will treat the patient conservatively at first with a brace and pain medication (50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours). The patient will undergo surgery, followed by physical therapy 3 times per week. The patient will wear the brace for 6 weeks post-surgery. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in 1 month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will contact the office if her pain does not improve or worsens, or if she has any concerns or questions about her treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Edema and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing pain and swelling in the right knee. Physical exam and x-ray results support the diagnosis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support. Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to elevate and rest the leg, avoiding strenuous activities for a couple of weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to help manage blood pressure and potentially reduce the need for medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to feel like she might fall. The pain is located internally and affects the whole kneecap. The patient denies hearing or feeling a pop and cannot recall any specific injury to the knee. The pain is not severe and does not last long, so the patient has not taken any medication for it. The patient is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to the knee instability.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Reports a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: BP 122/70, HR 72, RR 16, Temp 98.2 F.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
MSK: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, or effusion; no pain to palpation; full range of motion; negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and make any necessary adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports having good family support and has been accompanied by family members during her treatments.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Reports sore throat, no difficulty swallowing or sensation of food getting stuck.
Psychiatric: Patient reports feeling emotionally and mentally strong with good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, likely related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with the current regimen of cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy and current dose of radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve cough and shortness of breath.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent international travel to Zambia. Patient's family owns a donut shop.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is on Metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness or diarrhea.

VITALS

All vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS

Recent lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low Immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other concerning symptoms.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check other antibody levels to rule out other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency with the patient and advised them to watch for persistent infections or severe diarrhea. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. He has been experiencing pain for approximately 4 days. The patient reports that the pain began after engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic. The pain is localized to the inside of his right elbow and radiates slightly into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the management of his current symptoms. The patient is advised to rest the affected elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day. He is prescribed ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. The patient is advised to refrain from pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in one week to assess his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: Denies any issues.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting his sodium intake. He could try keeping a food diary, as previously discussed, to log his diet and associated blood pressure readings. I also advised him to monitor his weight daily and contact me if he gains 3 pounds in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding his diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: He can continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in waves. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief and reports feeling nauseated but not vomiting.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Abdominal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and burning sensation during urination.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone (acute nephrolithiasis).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for further analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to check on the patient's progress. If symptoms have not improved, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient has been experiencing a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the ulcer has turned black around the edges. He has also been experiencing calf cramping and a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle. The patient has been on antibiotics for 6 days and has a few days left in the course. He reports pain in the affected area and difficulty catching his breath when walking around the house.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His last A1c was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently went on a hike with new diabetic shoes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports difficulty catching breath when walking around the house.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No reported issues.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot exam: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and odor. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler. No pain upon pressing the affected area.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes
3. Diabetic neuropathy

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed that his right foot ulcer is fairly sizable and will require wound care. I advised him that the ulcer does not appear to be healing and that further studies will be needed to assess if he has adequate blood supply to heal his foot wound. He was advised that due to his diabetes it is possible surgical intervention such as stent placement or bypass surgery may be required to improve his blood supply. I also advised him that I believe we will be able to heal his wound. At this time, I have recommended continued wound care and for him to also continue taking his current antibiotics. We will order an arterial ultrasound of the lower extremities. He will also be referred to podiatry for a consult.

Regarding his diabetes, this appears to be unstable as the patient reports his blood sugars have been trending higher than normal. We discussed the importance of blood sugar control as this will impact his wound healing. At this time, I have recommended that he follow-up with his endocrinologist for further care.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports a tick bite on the right knee that occurred over a week ago. The area around the bite is warm and has a burning sensation. Patient has not experienced fever or chills but reports a headache and not feeling well since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys outdoor activities, including hunting and working in the yard.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain in joints.
Neurological: Reports headache.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not recorded
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Presence of bull's-eye rash and patient's outdoor activities increase the risk of Lyme disease.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm the diagnosis.
- Medical Treatment: Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order Hemoglobin A1C to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
